title: 'Homeland' accidentally broadcasts anti-show graffiti
text:
'Homeland' accidentally broadcasts anti-show graffiti Compiled by Tony Hicks Posted: 10/15/2015 10:30:57 AM PDT Updated: 10/15/2015 10:32:50 AM PDT "Homeland" got punked. 
Berlin street artists hired to paint Arabic street graffiti on the set of the hit Showtime series, actually painted slogans ripping the show that made it into last weekend's episode, according to Time.com . 
"There is no Homeland," "Homeland is racist," and "This show does not represent the views of the artists" ended up painted onto sets by a group calling itself The Arabian Street Artists, which reportedly include artists Heba Amin and Caram Kapp. 
A statement on Amin's website says "Homeland" is "the most bigoted and racist TV series." The show has been criticized in some circles for its depictions of the Middle East and Muslims. Claire Danes as Carrie Mathison and Damian Lewis as Nicholas "Nick" Brody in "Homeland." (Photo by Kent Smith/Showtime) 
The show's co-creator, Alex Gansa, told Time in a statement, "We wish we'd caught these images before they made it to air. However, as Homeland always strives to be subversive in its own right and a stimulus for conversation, we can't help but admire this act of artistic sabotage." 
In other words, we appreciate the publicity. 
The artists said there job was to lend authenticity to a set outside Berlin meant to portray a Syrian refugee camp. 
It seems they did their job. 
"The set decoration had to be completed in two days, for filming on the third," they said in a statement. "Set designers were too frantic to pay any attention to us; they were busy constructing a hyper-realistic set that addressed everything from the plastic laundry pins to the frayed edges of outdoor plastic curtains. It looked very Middle Eastern and the summer sun and heat helped heighten that illusion. The content of what was written on the walls, however, was of no concern." Advertisement 
Time reports Amin -- a self-described "Egyptian visual artist, researcher and, currently, visiting assistant professor at the American University in Cairo" -- didn't respond to a request for comment.
